metadata.title: US Imposes New Tariffs on Trading Partners
metadata.description: President Trump announces new tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China, citing concerns over fentanyl trafficking and illegal immigration.
metadata.author: Financial Times

events.text: After Hamas’s surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7, Israel has been besieging and bombarding the Gaza Strip, worsening a humanitarian crisis.
Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

On Oct. 7, Hamas led a surprise attack on towns, a music festival, army bases and other locations in Israel, killing roughly 1,200 people and taking about 240 hostages, including children, according to the Israeli government.
Israeli officials vowed to destroy Hamas, the Palestinian group that controls the Gaza Strip and is considered a terrorist organization by the United States, Israel and other countries.
Israel has since besieged Gaza in one of the most intense bombing campaigns of this century, and launched a ground invasion.
More than 11,000 Palestinians, including more than 4,600 children, have been killed since the Israeli campaign began, according to Gaza’s health ministry.
The violence, its fallout and the humanitarian crisis afflicting Gazan civilians have shaken the region and the world.
Early on Oct. 7, Hamas fired volleys of rockets that struck as far away as Tel Aviv and the outskirts of Jerusalem.
The attackers also infiltrated border communities and army bases, as well as an outdoor music festival, opening fire on men, women and children.
It took days for Israeli forces to regain control after the attack.
Hamas and other armed Palestinian groups also took about 240 civilians and soldiers hostage.
Four have since been released.
After the Hamas attack on Oct. 7, the Israeli military soon began a siege to block food, water, and fuel from entering the territory, and it launched a ground invasion on Oct. 27.
Israeli troops encircled Gaza City on Nov. 7, effectively splitting control of the strip in half.
On Nov. 17, Israel signaled that it was preparing to expand military operations into southern Gaza, where Palestinians had been told to evacuate.
More than one million Palestinians have been displaced following Israel’s warnings for civilians to leave northern Gaza, aid workers say.
Many Gazans say no part of the enclave is safe.

Israel says Hamas uses civilian structures, including hospitals, as bases for military operations in violation of international law; areas including medical centers, schools, mosques and residential locations have been struck under Israel’s bombardment.
Palestinians and some international observers have accused Israel of breaking the law with a disproportionate military response.

On Nov. 15, the Israeli military stormed Gaza’s largest hospital, Al-Shifa, and said it discovered weapons and other evidence to support its assertions that Hamas operated in a network of tunnels under the complex.
Senior U.S. officials have backed Israel, though the Israeli military has yet to show incontrovertible proof of a vast Hamas tunnel network.
Hamas and hospital officials had denied the accusations.

Almost two days after Israel began its raid of Al-Shifa, New York Times journalists were taken on a controlled tour of the complex by Israeli military officials, and saw a shaft on the hospital grounds.
Electrical wiring was visible inside, along with a metal staircase, but it was unclear how deep the shaft was or where it led.
As conditions have worsened for civilians in Gaza, Israel’s campaign has drawn increasing outcries from the United Nations, aid organizations and much of the world.

Without challenging Israel’s right to defend itself, the Biden administration has repeatedly called for “humanitarian pauses” to protect Palestinian civilians and allow the delivery of desperately needed aid.
After more than a month of war, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza has grown increasingly dire, leaving Gazans with severely limited access to food, clean water and medical care.
The United Nations has warned that the entire territory is at risk of starvation amid mass internal displacement.
Thousands of children, who make up nearly half of Gaza’s population, have been killed, according to health officials.

After weeks of desperate fuel shortages that put hospitals on the verge of collapse, Israel agreed on Nov. 17 to the entry of two tankers of fuel into Gaza each day to operate desalination and sewage plants.
Before Israel’s raid of Al-Shifa, the hospital complex had been struggling to treat patients, with operations limited by a dearth of supplies, including water, medicine and oxygen.
Medical workers at other hospitals have described similar scenes of operations at the verge of collapse.
Violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank has also sharply escalated since Oct. 7.
About 200 Palestinians have been killed in confrontations with Israeli forces and in escalating settler attacks, local officials say.
Freeing the 240 hostages abducted by Hamas on Oct. 7 has been one of Israel’s two main goals of the war, in addition to destroying Hamas.
Since Oct. 7, Hamas has released four Israeli hostages, while Israeli troops rescued a 19-year-old Israeli soldier in October.
Hamas has published some videos of hostages on social media, which Israel has called psychological terrorism.

Following Israel’s raid of the Al-Shifa hospital, Israeli soldiers said they found the bodies of two Israeli hostages nearby, which they called an indication that Hamas used the complex for military operations.

Negotiations for a deal that would have exchanged 50 women and children captives with roughly the same number of Palestinian women and children held in Israeli prisons had been underway, according to Israeli officials.
In the immediate aftermath of the Oct. 7 attacks, many world leaders condemned Hamas and affirmed their support for Israel.
President Biden visited to show solidarity, as did the leaders of Britain, France and Germany.
But the strong support for Israel has since been tempered by calls for restraint from its allies, while protesters across the world have been calling for a cease-fire.
Aid groups are warning about the spiraling crisis in Gaza.
On Nov. 16, the U.N. Security Council adopted a resolution calling for days-long humanitarian pauses to the fighting in Gaza.
António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, is among the leaders who has called for a humanitarian cease-fire.
Leaders of dozens of Arab and Muslim nations convened in Saudi Arabia in mid-November.
They also called for a cease-fire and avoided blaming Hamas, but those with ties to Israel have not cut off relations.

The war in Gaza is straining relations between Israel and its immediate neighbors, jeopardizing months of U.S. diplomacy to push Saudi Arabia to normalize ties with Israel, leading to protests across the Middle East and the world and stoking fears of a broader regional conflict.
President Biden has sought to prevent the war between Israel and Hamas from spilling over into a fight with Iran and its proxies in Lebanon, Syria and Iraq.
The Pentagon sent two aircraft carriers and dozens of extra warplanes to the region to make this point.
Since the Oct. 7 attacks, the Israeli army has engaged in almost daily clashes with Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group allied with Hamas and backed by Iran.
Israel’s military also has responded to fire from Syria.

The Palestinian Authority, which controls parts of the West Bank, said on Nov. 9 it would be open to a role overseeing a post-Hamas Gaza as long as the Biden administration commits to a two-state solution to end the war, according to a top Palestinian official.

The head of the authority, President Mahmoud Abbas, met with U.S. officials in Ramallah on Nov. 15, urging them to pressure Israel to stop the war, speed up humanitarian aid and crack down on violence in the West Bank.
But Mr. Netanyahu said on NBC’s “Meet the Press” on Nov. 12 that his postwar vision would not include the Palestinian Authority in the near term.
Earlier, he had said that Israel would indefinitely “have the overall security responsibility” of the enclave, though he seemed to stop short of suggesting a full re-occupation of Gaza.
His statement was at odds with the postwar plan that Secretary of State Antony Blinken suggested on Nov. 8, in which Gaza would be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.
